qas.question: Which year was it when paper money was first issued without the backing of precious metals?
What was the first war that caused paper money to be issued?
Which other war also caused a disconnect between paper money and precious metals?
The quick loss in value of paper money resulted in which phrase being hear?
The loss in value resulted in a clause being written in which article in the US Constitution?
Which year was it when paper money was first issued without the backing of the Articles of Confederation?
What was the first war that caused silver money to be issued?
Which other war also caused a disconnect between the United States Constitution?
The quick loss in value of silver resulted in which phrase being heard?
The loss in value resulted in a clause being written in which article in the Articles of Confederation?

context: In 1862, paper money was issued without the backing of precious metals, due to the <a1_0><b6_0>Civil War<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Silver and gold coins continued to be issued and in 1878 the link between paper money and coins was reinstated. This disconnection from gold and silver backing also occurred during the <a2_0><b7_0>War of 1812<b7_0/><a2_0/>. The use of paper money not backed by precious metals had also occurred under the Articles of Confederation from <a0_0><b5_0>1777<b5_0/><a0_0/> to 1788. With no solid backing and being easily counterfeited, the continentals quickly lost their value, giving rise to the phrase <a3_0>"<b8_0>not worth a continental<b8_0/>"<a3_0/>. This was a primary reason for the "No state shall... make any thing but gold and silver coin a tender in payment of debts" clause in <a4_0><b9_0>article 1<b9_0/><a4_0/>, section 10 of the United States Constitution.
